I am not saying that the following story is true or false, but that I was told this in first-person, by the man it happened to, whom I do know very well and that I consider to be a trustworthy individual:
 Harold was about 40 yrs old back then, in the fall of 1989. He always fished in the area known as Mercer Bayou in southern Arkansas since he was a child. He was never afraid to stay all night along the banks at any given time. After years of hearing about a large, hairy human-like creature that prowled the creek bottoms he laughed it off, declaring there was no such thing. One moonlit night in October, as he was running his trotlines, he felt a particularly hard pull on the line. Thinking it was a large catfish, he ran the line quickly to that drop. Once there he tugged on the line trying to pull it out of the water to no avail. As he sat back and got his breath, a large hairy creature burst to the surface and ripped the hook from its shoulder, letting out a blood-curdling scream.
 Harold couldn’t recall what happened next, but “found” himself at the door of a house a few miles away knocking on the door and yelling, not a thread of clothing wet.
 Now, what he saw, or if it really exists, is moot: The fact that he now believes it exists is the point.
 I know this analogy is farfetched, maybe even ridiculous, but the point is that we may hear and never believe, but once we see (either physically or spiritually) we do, or at least begin to believe.
 As far as the article (web page) you referred to, I agree with part of it, but not all of it, especially the part about “…God gives up on man.” Man can turn from God, but God will never turn from man.
 I have not always believed as I do today, but I can say, with confidence, that any person that knows God will love Him, unconditionally. To know God like that and then blaspheme Him, is a “sin unto death.”
